Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nations title, which was akin to confederate action partys slogans we are one nation and one flag one nation.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nations expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisisthe cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading new world ordermuch of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tonys wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archers criticism of hanson that led to archers expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australias leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: YES

Text: the australians south australian contact, algie walker, claimed to be a member of one nation and, according to west australian organizer alan rossiter, he and all his members joined one nation to whom they donated their funds.26 reflecting the extent to which confederate action party was the foundation on which one nation stood, the one nation support movement was established and led by former confederate action party candidate bruce whiteside. it was through whiteside, who expressed his adulation for hanson by telling her i can honestly say i love you,27 that a grassroots movement was established through which tens of thousands of australians were mobilized to rally and vote for hanson.

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nations title, which was akin to confederate action partys slogans we are one nation and one flag one nation.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nations expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisisthe cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading new world ordermuch of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tonys wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archers criticism of hanson that led to archers expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australias leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: YES, husband and wife

Text: greason (1997) described them as developing since the second world war in three broad waves: the explicitly nazi nationalist socialist party of australia (nspa) in the 1960s; the less symbolically laden (that is, no swastikas) national front of australia and the australian national alliance during the 1970s and early 1980s; and national action (na) from the early 1980s onwards. a return to explicit nazi ideology and paraphernalia was evident in the national action breakaway group, the australian nationalist movement (australian nationalist movement), formed in 1984 because its leader believed that national action was insufficiently explicit in its anti-semitism and neo-naziism.
attributes.response: [YES, 'The explicitly nazi National Socialist Party of Australia (NSPA) in the 1960s']

Text: shout, im proud to be a militiaman or reservist in the patriotic sense. i am proud to carry a firearm in defence of my australia.42 indeed, the partys queensland mps invested considerable time and resources in a bill to liberalize gun ownership, which declared that disarming law abiding australians is not in the national interest.43 32 a gun culture permeated the party; south australian president len spencer wore a concealed gun at one nation meetings.44 it was this culture that attracted the militias, with australians united survival individual freedom scouts queensland director ron heppes openly admitting that most of his people were either one nation members or supporters.45 hanson welcomed militia leaders, many of whom were associated with the league of rights, at the highest levels of the party.

Text: the groups also appeared to share a belief in the politicized nature of the courts, demonstrated after hanson was fined and the party deregistered by the australian electoral commission. as the adelaide institute said: the courts have quite obviously, and most probably unlawfully, taken the law into their own hands and set out to destroy an individual in the hopes of squashing a growing political movement.68 the adelaide institute was joined by australias other main holocaust-denial organization, the australian civil liberties union (aclu), headed by john bennett, which published praiseworthy statements in hansons defence.69 as tben agreed with hanson about the courts, bennett appeared to do likewise in relation to the elitism of the media, arguing that there was a campaign against hanson by commentators, many of whom doubtless see themselves as part of some sort of cultural and intellectual elite.70 although there is no record of hanson espousing holocaust denial there were holocaust-deniers in the party.
attributes.response: [YES, 'aclu published praiseworthy statements in hanson\'s defence']

Text: greason (1997) described them as developing since the second world war in three broad waves: the explicitly nazi nationalist socialist party of australia (nspa) in the 1960s; the less symbolically laden (that is, no swastikas) national front of australia and the australian national alliance during the 1970s and early 1980s; and national action (na) from the early 1980s onwards. a return to explicit nazi ideology and paraphernalia was evident in the national action breakaway group, the australian nationalist movement (australian nationalist movement), formed in 1984 because its leader believed that national action was insufficiently explicit in its anti-semitism and neo-naziism.
attributes.response: [YES, 'The explicitly nazi National Socialist Party of Australia (NSPA) in the 1960s']

Text: greason (1997) described them as developing since the second world war in three broad waves: the explicitly nazi nationalist socialist party of australia (nspa) in the 1960s; the less symbolically laden (that is, no swastikas) national front of australia and the australian national alliance during the 1970s and early 1980s; and national action (na) from the early 1980s onwards. a return to explicit nazi ideology and paraphernalia was evident in the national action breakaway group, the australian nationalist movement (australian nationalist movement), formed in 1984 because its leader believed that national action was insufficiently explicit in its anti-semitism and neo-naziism.

Text: if australians looked behind the [one nation] banner and saw some of these old faces coming out again, federal treasurer peter costello said, referring to the league of rights, they would be horrified to know who is behind it and who has a very significant influence in it.2 costellos comment was triggered by one nations economic policy of 2 per cent low-interest loans, and an off-the-cuff call by one nation director david ettridge for printing more money, both of which were policies long advocated by the league of rights. by its own admission the league of rights identified with hanson; its octogenarian leader eric butler stated that the league of rights agreed with her views and policies.3 describing the hanson miracle as a catalyst in a type of political turning-point in australian politics, he argued: the value of pauline hansons service to australian politics is incalculable, and will only be seen in its true perspective in time to come.4 it followed that the league of rights encouraged its activists to support her,5 while its outlets sold copies of the truth, the racist tract published by hansons support movement described below.

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nations title, which was akin to confederate action partys slogans we are one nation and one flag one nation.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nations expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisisthe cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading new world ordermuch of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tonys wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archers criticism of hanson that led to archers expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australias leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: [YES, 'peter archer, formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy']

Text: however, there was still room for co-operation: national action stated that, with the right, it goes marching separately, striking together, while maintaining its independence.81 unlike other racist groups, such as australians against further immigration, which saw its future as dependent on and integrated with one nation, national action members believe the future is theirs for the taking. in the article one nation party/ australia first party crises: can nationalists fill the political gap?, they argue that national action can fill in where one nation and australia first have left off, that is, by organizing street level propaganda campaigns, secondary school activities, university actions and street demonstrations, and by build[ing] a party of effective cadres who can give leadership to australians in direct struggle.82 there is some recent evidence, albeit from far-right sources, that one nation members in the riverina region of new south wales have left the party and are seeking to establish a branch of national action.

Text: the true nature of the league of rights  one nation relationship was articulated by butlers successor, david thompson, who told the league of rights supporters they should resent claims that one nation is a the league of rights front, which he dismissed as an attempt to undermine support for hanson.6 in the organizations most explicit statement on one nation he wrote: while we have made every effort to distribute pauline hansons addresses as widely as possible, and offered every encouragement to others to support her in the raising of the issues with which she has become associated, the league of rights has had no contact with pauline hanson whatever (italic and underlined in original).7 furthermore, the league of rights joined the chorus of concern over the role and influence of ettridge and david oldfield, hansons political adviser, who with hanson became known as the troika, in creating an undemocratic party structure. the lack of formal ties did not, however, mean that the league of rights had no influence in one nation.
attributes.ent1_notes: crucial in the creation of One Nation

Text: if australians looked behind the [one nation] banner and saw some of these old faces coming out again, federal treasurer peter costello said, referring to the league of rights, they would be horrified to know who is behind it and who has a very significant influence in it.2 costellos comment was triggered by one nations economic policy of 2 per cent low-interest loans, and an off-the-cuff call by one nation director david ettridge for printing more money, both of which were policies long advocated by the league of rights. by its own admission the league of rights identified with hanson; its octogenarian leader eric butler stated that the league of rights agreed with her views and policies.3 describing the hanson miracle as a catalyst in a type of political turning-point in australian politics, he argued: the value of pauline hansons service to australian politics is incalculable, and will only be seen in its true perspective in time to come.4 it followed that the league of rights encouraged its activists to support her,5 while its outlets sold copies of the truth, the racist tract published by hansons support movement described below.
attributes.response: [YES, 'One Nation's economic policy and call for printing more money were influenced by the League of Rights, which identified with Hanson']

Text: evonne moore, an unley city councillor (adelaide) and australians against further immigration candidate, has analysed the growth of an anti-immigration impulse in the australian environmentalist movement.81 she explained the development of a population debate within the australian conservation foundation centred around dr. geoff mosley.82 it occasioned a dilemma, whereby some environmentalists believed they would be accused of racism in pushing for immigration-restriction, and while employing rhetoric about sustainability, they abandoned the field.83 the gap was filled by australians for an ecologically sustainable population, writers for an ecologically sustainable population (supported by poets judith wright and mark oconnor) - and australians against immigration. the former groups specifically repudiated any idea of racial preference.
attributes.response: YES, evonne moore is a member of australians against immigration.

Text: greason (1997) described them as developing since the second world war in three broad waves: the explicitly nazi nationalist socialist party of australia (nspa) in the 1960s; the less symbolically laden (that is, no swastikas) national front of australia and the australian national alliance during the 1970s and early 1980s; and national action (na) from the early 1980s onwards. a return to explicit nazi ideology and paraphernalia was evident in the national action breakaway group, the australian nationalist movement (australian nationalist movement), formed in 1984 because its leader believed that national action was insufficiently explicit in its anti-semitism and neo-naziism.

Text: as a result of this process, australians against further immigrations immigration policy became one nations policy, reflected in the latters call for zero net immigration and tighter testing for tuberculosis and hepatitis b.13 it was a process in which rodney spencer went from the extreme fringe to holding well-attended press conferences in parliament house. while australians against further immigration were the main anti-immigrant group of the 1990s, smaller, essentially one-man, xenophobic parties also affiliated to one nation.

Text: the groups also appeared to share a belief in the politicized nature of the courts, demonstrated after hanson was fined and the party deregistered by the australian electoral commission. as the adelaide institute said: the courts have quite obviously, and most probably unlawfully, taken the law into their own hands and set out to destroy an individual in the hopes of squashing a growing political movement.68 the adelaide institute was joined by australias other main holocaust-denial organization, the australian civil liberties union (aclu), headed by john bennett, which published praiseworthy statements in hansons defence.69 as tben agreed with hanson about the courts, bennett appeared to do likewise in relation to the elitism of the media, arguing that there was a campaign against hanson by commentators, many of whom doubtless see themselves as part of some sort of cultural and intellectual elite.70 although there is no record of hanson espousing holocaust denial there were holocaust-deniers in the party.

Text: the groups also appeared to share a belief in the politicized nature of the courts, demonstrated after hanson was fined and the party deregistered by the australian electoral commission. as the adelaide institute said: the courts have quite obviously, and most probably unlawfully, taken the law into their own hands and set out to destroy an individual in the hopes of squashing a growing political movement.68 the adelaide institute was joined by australias other main holocaust-denial organization, the australian civil liberties union (aclu), headed by john bennett, which published praiseworthy statements in hansons defence.69 as tben agreed with hanson about the courts, bennett appeared to do likewise in relation to the elitism of the media, arguing that there was a campaign against hanson by commentators, many of whom doubtless see themselves as part of some sort of cultural and intellectual elite.70 although there is no record of hanson espousing holocaust denial there were holocaust-deniers in the party.

Text: the true nature of the league of rights  one nation relationship was articulated by butlers successor, david thompson, who told the league of rights supporters they should resent claims that one nation is a the league of rights front, which he dismissed as an attempt to undermine support for hanson.6 in the organizations most explicit statement on one nation he wrote: while we have made every effort to distribute pauline hansons addresses as widely as possible, and offered every encouragement to others to support her in the raising of the issues with which she has become associated, the league of rights has had no contact with pauline hanson whatever (italic and underlined in original).7 furthermore, the league of rights joined the chorus of concern over the role and influence of ettridge and david oldfield, hansons political adviser, who with hanson became known as the troika, in creating an undemocratic party structure. the lack of formal ties did not, however, mean that the league of rights had no influence in one nation.
attributes.response: YES, David Oldfield is mentioned as Pauline Hanson's political adviser.

Text: the truths claim that australia was legally acquired by britain, its denial of genocide and assertion that aborigines were not indigenous to australia, but immigrants like everyone else, provided the basis upon which one nation could assert its opposition to land rights. the truths contributors included south australian academic joseph wayne smith, who was chairman of the league of rights off-shoot australian patriots,33 and australians against further immigrations denis mccormack.34 overall, although there was clear confederate action party influence in one nation, it is wrong to conclude from these contacts that confederate action party controlled one nation.

Text: 36 one nation was built on the foundations of the anti-aboriginal land rights movement, they attributed this movement to the larouchite idea that land rights are a plot developed by prince philip.75 the cec claimed that, while hanson had taken and benefitted from these larouchite ideas, she apparently did not attribute them to larouche or acknowledge his role as she did not wish to be seen to be associated with him.76 while these claims were larouchite/cec hyperbole, there was some common ground between the cec and one nation. ross bensted, for example, one-time editor of the citizen electoral councils publication new citizen, was president of the one nation gladstone branch.

Text: just as one nation did not emerge in isolation, but rather on the foundations of the confederate action party, it is likely to give rise to other extremist organizations. to date this includes the city country alliance and the australian one nation party established by disenchanted members,94 as was the australian united peoples movement, whose co-founders include john abbott, a former one nation national vice-president.95 none of these are likely to pose a serious electoral threat, but they provide another front for the far right with which both one nation and the wider community will have to contend.

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nations title, which was akin to confederate action partys slogans we are one nation and one flag one nation.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nations expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisisthe cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading new world ordermuch of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tonys wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archers criticism of hanson that led to archers expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australias leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: YES, 'David Ettridge was given secret recordings by Tony Pitt's wife, leading to Peter Archer's expulsion.'

Text: however, there was still room for co-operation: national action stated that, with the right, it goes marching separately, striking together, while maintaining its independence.81 unlike other racist groups, such as australians against further immigration, which saw its future as dependent on and integrated with one nation, national action members believe the future is theirs for the taking. in the article one nation party/ australia first party crises: can nationalists fill the political gap?, they argue that national action can fill in where one nation and australia first have left off, that is, by organizing street level propaganda campaigns, secondary school activities, university actions and street demonstrations, and by build[ing] a party of effective cadres who can give leadership to australians in direct struggle.82 there is some recent evidence, albeit from far-right sources, that one nation members in the riverina region of new south wales have left the party and are seeking to establish a branch of national action.

Text: 36 one nation was built on the foundations of the anti-aboriginal land rights movement, they attributed this movement to the larouchite idea that land rights are a plot developed by prince philip.75 the cec claimed that, while hanson had taken and benefitted from these larouchite ideas, she apparently did not attribute them to larouche or acknowledge his role as she did not wish to be seen to be associated with him.76 while these claims were larouchite/cec hyperbole, there was some common ground between the cec and one nation. ross bensted, for example, one-time editor of the citizen electoral councils publication new citizen, was president of the one nation gladstone branch.

Text: the true nature of the league of rights  one nation relationship was articulated by butlers successor, david thompson, who told the league of rights supporters they should resent claims that one nation is a the league of rights front, which he dismissed as an attempt to undermine support for hanson.6 in the organizations most explicit statement on one nation he wrote: while we have made every effort to distribute pauline hansons addresses as widely as possible, and offered every encouragement to others to support her in the raising of the issues with which she has become associated, the league of rights has had no contact with pauline hanson whatever (italic and underlined in original).7 furthermore, the league of rights joined the chorus of concern over the role and influence of ettridge and david oldfield, hansons political adviser, who with hanson became known as the troika, in creating an undemocratic party structure. the lack of formal ties did not, however, mean that the league of rights had no influence in one nation.
attributes.response: [YES, 'The league of rights joined the chorus of concern over the role and influence of ettridge and david oldfield, hansons political adviser, who with hanson became known as the troika, in creating an undemocratic party structure.']

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nations title, which was akin to confederate action partys slogans we are one nation and one flag one nation.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nations expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisisthe cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading new world ordermuch of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tonys wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archers criticism of hanson that led to archers expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australias leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: YES, 'Tony Pitt was a former member of the confederate action party and later became a leading figure in the far-right Wake Up Australia!'

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nations title, which was akin to confederate action partys slogans we are one nation and one flag one nation.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nations expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisisthe cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading new world ordermuch of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tonys wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archers criticism of hanson that led to archers expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australias leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: [YES, 'Tony Pitt gave secret recordings to David Ettridge']

Text: one nation and confederate action party policies were almost identical, be they on immigration and land rights or on the repeal of the family law act and introduction of citizen-initiated referenda.16 another similarity was one nations title, which was akin to confederate action partys slogans we are one nation and one flag one nation.17 when one nation queensland mps started to use the expression, all that is required for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing, they were repeating an axiom of the confederate action party (and the league of rights).18 these similarities help explain why former confederate action party officials such as paul hilderbrand felt disposed to join one nation as ordinary members. according to one nations expelled harvey bay organizer and would-be newcastle candidate peter archer, himself formerly on the staff of the far-right paper the strategy and author of the 1993 book the australian crisisthe cover of which shows the globe of the world encircled with a banner reading new world ordermuch of the right-wing shift in the party could be attributed to tony pitt.19 archer was speaking from personal experience as it was tonys wife pat, who stood on the one nation ticket in the 1998 queensland election, who gave one nation director david ettridge the secret recordings she made of archers criticism of hanson that led to archers expulsion.20 after leaving confederate action party, tony pitt became one of australias leading far-right figures, propagating his ideas through his self-published papers the national interest, wake up australia!
attributes.response: [YES, 'Tony Pitt became one of Australias leading far-right figures and editor of the national interest.']

Text: 36 one nation was built on the foundations of the anti-aboriginal land rights movement, they attributed this movement to the larouchite idea that land rights are a plot developed by prince philip.75 the cec claimed that, while hanson had taken and benefitted from these larouchite ideas, she apparently did not attribute them to larouche or acknowledge his role as she did not wish to be seen to be associated with him.76 while these claims were larouchite/cec hyperbole, there was some common ground between the cec and one nation. ross bensted, for example, one-time editor of the citizen electoral councils publication new citizen, was president of the one nation gladstone branch.
attributes.ent1_notes: president of the one nation gladstone branch
attributes.response: YES
